{{Infobox military person | name = Aristotelis Vlachopoulos | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1866{{Greece Old Style dating}} | death_date = 1960 | birth_place = [[Corfu]] | death_place = [[Athens]] | allegiance = {{flagicon|Greece|royal}} [[Kingdom of Greece]] | branch = [[Hellenic Army]] | serviceyears = 1887–1917, 1920–28 | rank = [[File:GR-Army-OF8-1912.svg|15px]] [[Lieutenant General]] | servicenumber = | commands = | battles = [[Greco-Turkish War of 1897]], [[Balkan Wars]], [[Greco-Turkish War of 1919–22]] | battles_label = Wars | awards = [[Cross of Valour (Greece)|Cross of Valour]] in Gold<ref name="bio"/> | relations = | laterwork = }} '''Aristotelis Vlachopoulos''' ({{lang-el|Αριστοτέλης Βλαχόπουλος}}, 1866–1960) was a [[Greece|Greek]] Army officer who rose to the rank of [[lieutenant general]] and served as Chief of the [[Hellenic Army General Staff]] in 1920–21.
== Life == He was born in [[Corfu]] in 1866. He entered the [[Hellenic Army Academy]] and graduated on 12 August 1887 as an artillery second lieutenant. Promoted to lieutenant in 1892, he fought in the [[Greco-Turkish War of 1897]] as a battery commander. He was subsequently appointed to the Army Staff Service, and served in it until 1913, being promoted to captain (1902), major (1910) and lieutenant colonel (1912).<ref name="bio">{{cite book | title = Συνοπτική Ιστορία του Γενικού Επιτελείου Στρατού 1901–2001 | trans_title = A Concise History of the Hellenic Army General Staff 1901–2001 | year = 2001 | publisher = Army History Directorate | location = Athens | language = Greek | chapter=Αντιστράτηγος ΒΛΑΧΟΠΟΥΛΟΣ ΑΡΙΣΤΟΤΕΛΗΣ του ΙΩΑΝΝΟΥ, ΑΜ 3584. | page=144 }}</ref> In May 1914 he was placed as [[military attache]] to the Greek embassy to [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]] (then bound to Greece with a [[Greek-Serbian Alliance of 1913|defensive alliance]]), returning in August 1915 to assume the direction of the Army Academy. Due to the mobilization ordered in September 1915, when Greek PM [[Eleftherios Venizelos]] prepared to come to Serbia's aid against the [[Serbian Campaign (World War I)|Austrian attack]], the Academy was dismissed and Vlachopoulos was placed in command of the [[V Army Corps (Greece)|V Army Corps]] at [[Patras]]. During the [[National Schism]], he sided with [[Constantine I of Greece|King Constantine I]] against Venizelos. He remained at Patras until May 1917, when he returned to head the Army Academy. After King Constantine's forced exile in June and the assumption of leadership by Venizelos, Vlachopoulos was suspended from active service and forcibly retired.<ref name="bio"/>
Following the Venizelist electoral defeat in November 1920, he was recalled to active duty and placed as Chief of the Army Staff Service. Soon, however, he requested and received a transfer to an operational command in [[Asia Minor]], where he commanded the [[III Army Corps (Greece)|III Army Corps]] (January–May 1921) and [[II Army Corps (Greece)|II Army Corps]] (May–July 1921). He was then placed in charge of the Asia Minor Superior General Military Command, which covered the rear areas of the [[Army of Asia Minor]], and in June 1922 he was dispatched to [[Eastern Thrace]] to assume command of the [[IV Army Corps (Greece)|IV Army Corps]]. Following the defeat of the Greek army in Asia Minor by the [[Turkish National Movement|Turks]] in August 1922, he was dismissed from active command and suspended from active duty in November 1923. He finally retired in March 1928 after reaching the statutory age limit. He died in 1960.<ref name="bio"/>
